item.title: Delaware AG Seeking Bank to Advise on OpenAI Restructuring
item.description: Delaware’s attorney general is planning to hire an investment bank that would advise her office as it examines OpenAI’s restructuring plans aimed at drawing more investors, according to a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Willmer, Malathi Nayak

item.title: Musk Departs US Government With His Business Empire in Flux
item.description: Billionaire Elon Musk said Wednesday that his time as formal adviser to President Donald Trump is coming to a close, raising questions about the future of the Department of Government Efficiency effort he spearheaded.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte, Jennifer A Dlouhy, Dana Hull

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk

item.title: Spain Bets on 1 Million Migrants to Keep Its Economy Growing
item.description: The country is bucking European trends with its most ambitious migration push to date, including a proposal for a “mass regularization” of undocumented foreign workers.
item.dc:creator: Laura Millan, Yinka Ibukun, Daniel Basteiro

item.title: Why Poland’s Election Is a Barometer for Europe’s Populist Wave
item.description: Poland’s presidential election will determine whether the country can overhaul controversial judicial reforms and remain a reliable partner in the European Union after nearly a decade of divisive right-wing populism.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Skolimowski, Wojciech Moskwa

media:content.media:description: Poland’s presidential palace in Warsaw

item.title: US to Revoke Chinese Student Visas in Escalating Crackdown
item.description: The US plans to start “aggressively” revoking visas for Chinese students, Secretary of State Marco Rubio said, escalating the Trump administration’s push for greater scrutiny of foreigners attending American universities.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams, Ryan Chua, Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: Photo by Brooks Kraft LLC/Corbis via Getty Images)

item.title: Trump’s Global Tariffs Deemed Illegal, Blocked by Trade Court
item.description: The vast majority of President Donald Trump’s global tariffs were deemed illegal and blocked by the US trade court, dealing a major blow to a pillar of his economic agenda.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump

item.title: RFK Jr. Slams Medical Journals, Floats In-House Publishing Plan
item.description: US Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said he may bar government scientists from publishing in top medical journals, accusing publications like The New England Journal of Medicine of being “corrupt” and beholden to pharmaceutical companies.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gale

media:content.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: US Ally South Korea Set to Improve China Ties If Lee Wins Vote
item.description: A win for the left-of-center frontrunner in South Korea’s presidential election would likely herald more caution by Seoul over taking sides in US-China rivalry, a new effort to draw North Korea into dialogue and the potential for tension with Japan.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung speaks at a campaign event in Uijeongbu on May 20.

item.title: Eric Trump Says He’d Love to See Some Big Banks ‘Go Extinct’
item.description: Eric Trump told attendees at a cryptocurrency conference that he wants some big banks to “go extinct,” echoing complaints from other members of the Trump family about the traditional financial system.
item.dc:creator: Olga Kharif

media:content.media:description: Eric Trump on May 28.

item.title: Economists Cut Thai, Malaysian Growth Forecasts on Trade Turmoil
item.description: Economists have slashed forecasts for growth in Malaysia and Thailand as the export-dependent economies grapple with US President Donald Trump’s global trade war.
item.dc:creator: Tomoko Sato

media:content.media:description: Malaysia’s central bank said earlier this month that it has policy room to act, as it expects growth to fall below the official forecast this year.

item.title: Australia Aims to Avoid Panama Repeat in China Port Showdown
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is confronting a fresh diplomatic dilemma with China: How to fulfill a pledge to regain control of a strategic port without jeopardizing improved relations with his country’s largest trading partner.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott, James Mayger

media:content.media:description: The Port of Darwin in Australia.

item.title: UK Taps Ukraine Lessons to Plow £1 Billion Into Warfare Systems
item.description: The UK will invest more than £1 billion ($1.4 billion) in a new digital targeting system to allow the country’s armed forces to pinpoint and eliminate enemy targets more swiftly as part of a forthcoming revamp of Britain’s defensive capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: UK Defence Secretary John Healey.

item.title: Williams to Revive Disputed Gas Pipeline Projects in New York
item.description: Williams Cos. is preparing to revive plans for two scrapped pipelines that would deliver natural gas to New York.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Emma Sanchez

item.title: Trump Administration Cancels $3 Billion Loan to Troubled Sunnova Energy
item.description: The Trump Administration terminated a $3 billion loan guarantee awarded to Sunnova Energy Intentional Inc. after the solar company told officials it no longer intended to tap into the facility.
item.dc:creator: Mark Chediak

media:content.media:description: Solar panels on the roofs of homes in Tucson, Arizona, US, on Thursday, May 22, 2025. The House has passed a bill that would gut key clean-energy tax incentives, but Senate Republicans say they will make changes to the bill, including softening aggressive phaseouts of tax credits for clean electricity production. Photographer: Rebecca Noble/Bloomberg

item.title: Rapper NBA YoungBoy, Ex-Chicago Gang Leader Win Trump Clemency
item.description: President Donald Trump is offering clemency to the co-founder of a notorious Chicago gang, a rap artist and a music executive in the latest use of his pardon and commutation powers, according to a White House official.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: Rapper NBA YoungBoy performs in Atlanta in 2018.

item.title: Japan Expands Military Push Against China With US Stand in Doubt
item.description: Japan is stepping up efforts to deter China’s military ambitions in the Asia-Pacific as Tokyo and other US partners seek clarity from the Trump administration about its plans to counter Beijing’s power in the region.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Mari Kiyohara

media:content.media:description: Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba, center, during his visit to the Philippine Coast Guard Headquarters in Metro Manila, the Philippines, on April 30.

item.title: Hegseth Cuts Staff at Pentagon’s Independent Test Office
item.description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth ordered staff cuts at the congressionally mandated Pentagon office that oversees tests of major weapons systems, to ensure they’re effective and maintainable, before billions of dollars are spent on them.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio

media:content.media:description: Pete Hegseth

item.title: Portugal’s Far-Right Chega Shatters 50-Year Two Party Dominance
item.description: During Portugal’s recent election campaign, far-right Chega leader Andre Ventura argued that the two centrist parties that have ruled the nation for half a century have failed to increase living standards, control immigration and end systemic corruption.
item.dc:creator: Henrique Almeida

media:content.media:description: Andre Ventura

item.title: UK to Fast-Track First New Reservoirs as Water-Supply Risks Loom
item.description: The UK is fast-tracking the approval process for new reservoirs — the first in 30 years — as it seeks to secure water supplies for housing projects.
item.dc:creator: Priscila Azevedo Rocha

media:content.media:description: A woman relaxes on a paddleboard at the Ardingly Reservoir, operated by South East Water Ltd., near Haywards Heath, UK, on Friday, Aug. 12, 2022. Extreme heat and dry weather are putting intense pressure on England's water supply. Photographer: Carlos Jasso/Bloomberg

item.title: US Announces Visa Curbs Targeting Social Media ‘Censorship’
item.description: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio announced visa restrictions on foreign officials and other individuals who “censor Americans,” including those who target American technology companies, as the Trump administration steps up a confrontation with other countries over their social media policies.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: Marco Rubio, US secretary of state, during a Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, May 20, 2025. The hearing is reviewing the fiscal year 2026 budget request for the US Department of State.

item.title: Portugal President to Meet Parties Before Naming Prime Minister
item.description: Portuguese President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa will hold meetings with parties on Thursday after the May 18 election vote count was concluded.
item.dc:creator: Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa

item.title: Trump Bristles at ‘TACO Trade’ That Bets on Him Backing Down
item.description: President Donald Trump bristled at suggestions that Wall Street believes he’s ultimately unwilling to follow through on extreme tariff threats, saying his repeated retreats are instead part of a strategy to exert trade concessions.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Esha Dey

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump

item.title: Musk Joined by Some Senate Republicans Bemoaning Tax Bill’s Red Ink
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, congressional correspondent Steven T. Dennis looks at some of the Republican dissent over the tax and spending bill passed by the House . Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis

item.title: Milei Gets Tuttle Twins to Teach Free Markets to Argentine Kids
item.description: After denouncing it as a propaganda tool for the left, Argentina’s libertarian President Javier Milei is relaunching a state-run TV channel for kids set to feature a cartoon teaching free market economics while stressing the evils of taxes and communism.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Javier Milei, Argentina's president, during the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) in National Harbor, Maryland, US, on Saturday, Feb. 22, 2025. The Conservative Political Action Conference launched in 1974 brings together conservative organizations, elected leaders, and activists.

item.title: La ciudad china del litio resiste la caída de precios por la autosuficiencia que exige Pekín
item.description: Pekín quiere una economía de alta tecnología basada en el suministro interno, aunque el costo sea alto

media:content.media:description: A road in Yichun, known as China’s lithium mining capital, on March 19.

item.title: Boston Pushes Harvard, Other Colleges for Money Even as Trump Steps Up Attacks
item.description: Boston is pressuring Harvard University and other local colleges to funnel millions more into the city’s tax coffers, a push that’s becoming increasingly complicated as the Trump administration intensifies its attacks on higher education.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ryan

media:content.media:description: Michelle Wu

item.title: Germany’s Top Diplomat Expects New US Sanctions Against Russia
item.description: German Foreign Minister Johann Wadephul said after meeting his US counterpart Marco Rubio that he’s optimistic Washington will issue new sanctions against Russia if President Vladimir Putin continues to dodge a peace agreement with Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs, Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: Johann Wadephul

item.title: Why the Abortion Pill Mifepristone Is Under Renewed Scrutiny in the US
item.description: Since the US Supreme Court in 2022 overturned its Roe v. Wade decision establishing a nationwide right to an abortion, the fight over the intervention has focused largely on a pill that ends pregnancies: mifepristone. The court in June 2024 preserved the current level of access to medication abortion, the most common way to terminate a pregnancy in the country. Still, many states limit access to mifepristone, efforts continue to curtail it further, and leaders in the US Department of Health and
item.dc:creator: Jessica Nix, Kelsey Butler

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators outside the US Supreme Court in Washington, DC, in 2024.

item.title: Trump Says Harvard Should Cap Foreign Students at 15%
item.description: President Donald Trump said Harvard University should cap foreign student enrollment at 15%, ratcheting up his effort to force policy changes at the elite institution.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: Jeanine Pirro, interim US attorney for the District of Columbia, right, watches as US President Donald Trump speaks during a swearing-in ceremony in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 28, 2025.

item.title: Merz Vows Legislative Action to Quickly Boost German Economy
item.description: Germany’s new ruling coalition agreed to push ahead with measures aimed at stimulating the struggling economy and to enact as much legislation as possible before leaving for summer break in mid-July.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: Friedrich Merz, Germany's chancellor, during a news conference with Volodymyr Zelenskiy, Ukraine's president, at the Chancellery in Berlin, Germany, on Wednesday, May 28, 2025. Zelenskiy called on western allies to provide about $30 billion by the end of the year to boost domestic weapons production and hold off Russia’s advance.
